intro: Agalinis brachyphylla, commonly known as the short-leaved false foxglove, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the Acanthaceae family and is characterized by its erect, hairy stems and opposite, lance-shaped leaves. The plant produces clusters of tubular, two-lipped flowers that are typically pink to purple in color. It thrives in moist, sandy soils and is often found in open woodlands and along stream banks. Agalinis brachyphylla is an annual herb that plays a role in supporting pollinators such as bees and butterflies.
